title: AC Motors
explanation:
AC Motor Fundamentals

AC motors convert alternating current electrical energy into mechanical energy using rotating magnetic fields. They are the most common type of motor in industrial applications due to their simplicity, reliability, and low maintenance requirements.

Rotating Magnetic Field

The fundamental principle of AC motors is the creation of a rotating magnetic field by three-phase currents displaced by 120¬∞. When three-phase windings are energized by three-phase currents:

$i_R = I_m \sin(\omega t)$

$i_Y = I_m \sin(\omega t - 120¬∞)$

$i_B = I_m \sin(\omega t - 240¬∞)$

This creates a rotating magnetic field with constant magnitude rotating at synchronous speed:

$N_s = \frac{120f}{P}$ rpm or $\omega_s = \frac{4\pi f}{P}$ rad/s

Where:

  • $N_s$ = Synchronous speed (rpm)
  • f = Frequency (Hz)
  • P = Number of poles

üí° This rotating field is key to AC motor operation - it induces currents in the rotor which create torque.

Types of AC Motors

1. Induction Motors (Asynchronous)

  • Most common type (90% of industrial motors)
  • Rotor speed: $N_r < N_s$ (always less than synchronous)
  • Types:
    • Squirrel Cage: Simple, rugged, maintenance-free
    • Wound Rotor: External rotor resistance for speed control
  • Applications: Pumps, fans, compressors, conveyors

2. Synchronous Motors

  • Rotor runs at exactly synchronous speed: $N_r = N_s$
  • Rotor: DC excited (electromagnet) or permanent magnet
  • Can operate at leading, lagging, or unity power factor
  • Applications: Power factor correction, constant-speed drives, compressors

Slip in Induction Motors

Slip is the relative difference between synchronous speed and rotor speed:

$s = \frac{N_s - N_r}{N_s}$ (per unit) or $s = \frac{N_s - N_r}{N_s} \times 100\%$ (percentage)

Where $N_r$ is the rotor speed.

Key relationships:

  • Rotor speed: $N_r = N_s(1 - s)$
  • Rotor frequency: $f_r = s \cdot f$ (slip frequency)
  • At standstill: $s = 1$ (100%), $f_r = f$
  • At synchronous speed: $s = 0$ (0%), $f_r = 0$ (no torque!)
  • Normal running: $s = 0.02$ to $0.05$ (2-5%)

üéØ Slip is essential for torque production - without slip, no induced currents, no torque!

Torque-Slip Characteristics

The torque developed by an induction motor is:

$T = \frac{K \cdot s \cdot E_2^2 \cdot R_2}{R_2^2 + (s \cdot X_2)^2}$

Where K is a constant, $E_2$ is rotor EMF at standstill, $R_2$ is rotor resistance, and $X_2$ is rotor reactance at standstill.

Maximum Torque (Pull-out Torque):

Occurs when $R_2 = s \cdot X_2$, giving slip at maximum torque:

$s_m = \frac{R_2}{X_2}$

$T_{max} = \frac{K \cdot E_2^2}{2X_2}$

Note: $T_{max}$ is independent of $R_2$, but $s_m$ varies with $R_2$

Starting Methods

‚ö†Ô∏è Problem: Starting current = 5-7√ó full-load current

Squirrel Cage Motor Starting:

  • Direct-On-Line (DOL): Simple, but high starting current (small motors only)
  • Star-Delta Starter: Reduces starting current to 1/3, starting torque to 1/3
  • Auto-transformer Starter: Variable voltage starting with taps
  • Soft Starter: Electronic voltage control (modern method)

Wound Rotor Motor Starting:

  • External resistance in rotor circuit
  • Reduces starting current, increases starting torque
  • Resistance gradually reduced as motor speeds up

Speed Control Methods

Since $N_r = N_s(1-s) = \frac{120f}{P}(1-s)$, speed can be controlled by:

  • 1. Frequency Control (f): Using Variable Frequency Drive (VFD)
    • Most efficient and common method
    • Maintains constant V/f ratio for constant flux
    • Wide speed range with good efficiency
  • 2. Pole Changing (P): Multiple stator windings
    • Stepped speed control (e.g., 2-speed, 4-speed motors)
    • Common ratios: 2:1 (pole amplitude modulation method)
  • 3. Voltage Control (V): Reducing voltage
    • Limited range, reduced torque: $T \propto V^2$
    • Inefficient due to increased slip losses
  • 4. Rotor Resistance (Wound rotor): External resistance
    • Speed below base speed only
    • Poor efficiency, used for temporary control

Power Factor and Efficiency

Power Factor: Induction motors operate at lagging power factor

  • At no-load: PF ‚âà 0.1-0.2 (very poor)
  • At full-load: PF ‚âà 0.8-0.9 (good)
  • Can be improved using: Capacitor banks, Synchronous condensers

Efficiency: $\eta = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{in}} = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{out} + Losses}$

Losses: Stator copper loss + Rotor copper loss + Core loss + Mechanical loss + Stray loss

Typical efficiency: 85-95% for medium to large motors

Cost Low Medium High
Starting Torque Moderate High (controllable) Zero (needs starter)

quiz.question: What creates the rotating magnetic field in AC motors?
quiz.explanation: The rotating magnetic field in three-phase AC motors is created by three-phase currents: $i_R = I_m\sin(\omega t)$, $i_Y = I_m\sin(\omega t - 120¬∞)$, $i_B = I_m\sin(\omega t - 240¬∞)$ flowing through stator windings displaced by $120¬∞$ in space. This produces a smooth, constant-magnitude rotating field.

quiz.question: For a 4-pole, 50Hz AC motor, what is the synchronous speed?
quiz.explanation: Using the formula $N_s = \frac{120f}{P}$, we get: $N_s = \frac{120 \times 50}{4} = \frac{6000}{4} = 1500$ rpm. Synchronous speed is the speed at which the rotating magnetic field rotates and depends on supply frequency $f$ and number of poles $P$.

quiz.question: What is slip in an induction motor?
options: Difference between synchronous and rotor speed
quiz.explanation: Slip is the relative speed difference between the synchronous speed $N_s$ and actual rotor speed $N_r$, calculated as: $s = \frac{N_s - N_r}{N_s}$ (expressed as a fraction or percentage). Slip is essential for induction motor operation - without slip, there would be no relative motion, no induced currents (frequency $f_r = sf$), and no torque.

exercises.problem: A 3-phase induction motor has 4 poles and is connected to 50 Hz supply. Calculate the synchronous speed and the rotor speed if the slip is 4%.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • P = 4 poles
  • f = 50 Hz
  • Slip s = 4% = 0.04

Formulas:

$N_s = \frac{120f}{P}$

$N_r = N_s(1 - s)$

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Calculate synchronous speed

$N_s = \frac{120 \times 50}{4} = \frac{6000}{4} = 1500$ rpm

Step 2: Calculate rotor speed

$N_r = N_s(1 - s) = 1500 \times (1 - 0.04)$

$N_r = 1500 \times 0.96 = 1440$ rpm

Step 3: Final answer

Synchronous speed = 1500 rpm
Rotor speed = 1440 rpm

exercises.problem: A 6-pole, 50 Hz induction motor runs at 960 rpm. Calculate the slip and frequency of rotor current.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • P = 6 poles
  • f = 50 Hz
  • Nr = 960 rpm

Formulas:

$N_s = \frac{120f}{P}$

$s = \frac{N_s - N_r}{N_s}$

$f_r = s \times f$

Step-by-Step Solution:

Step 1: Calculate synchronous speed

$N_s = \frac{120 \times 50}{6} = 1000$ rpm

Step 2: Calculate slip

$s = \frac{N_s - N_r}{N_s} = \frac{1000 - 960}{1000} = \frac{40}{1000} = 0.04$

Slip = 0.04 or 4%

Step 3: Calculate rotor frequency

$f_r = s \times f = 0.04 \times 50 = 2$ Hz

Step 4: Final answer

Slip = 4%
Rotor frequency = 2 Hz

exercises.problem: A 3-phase, 400V, 50Hz, 4-pole star-connected induction motor has the following parameters: R‚ÇÅ = 1Œ©, R‚ÇÇ' = 0.5Œ© (referred to stator), X‚ÇÅ = 2Œ©, X‚ÇÇ' = 2Œ©. At a certain load, the motor runs with 3% slip. Calculate: (a) synchronous speed, (b) rotor speed, (c) rotor current per phase (neglect magnetizing branch), (d) rotor copper loss per phase.
exercises.solution:
Given:

  • Line voltage, VL = 400 V (star connection)
  • Frequency, f = 50 Hz
  • Poles, P = 4
  • Stator resistance, R‚ÇÅ = 1 Œ©
  • Rotor resistance (referred), R‚ÇÇ' = 0.5 Œ©
  • Stator reactance, X‚ÇÅ = 2 Œ©
  • Rotor reactance (referred), X‚ÇÇ' = 2 Œ©
  • Slip, s = 3% = 0.03

Step-by-Step Solution:

(a) Calculate Synchronous Speed:

$N_s = \frac{120f}{P} = \frac{120 \times 50}{4} = 1500$ rpm

(b) Calculate Rotor Speed:

$N_r = N_s(1-s) = 1500(1-0.03) = 1500 \times 0.97 = 1455$ rpm

(c) Calculate Rotor Current per Phase:

Phase voltage: $V_{ph} = \frac{V_L}{\sqrt{3}} = \frac{400}{\sqrt{3}} = 230.94$ V

Rotor reactance at slip s: $X_{2s}' = s \cdot X_2' = 0.03 \times 2 = 0.06$ Œ©

Total impedance per phase:

$Z = \sqrt{(R_1 + \frac{R_2'}{s})^2 + (X_1 + X_{2s}')^2}$

$Z = \sqrt{(1 + \frac{0.5}{0.03})^2 + (2 + 0.06)^2}$

$Z = \sqrt{(1 + 16.67)^2 + (2.06)^2}$

$Z = \sqrt{(17.67)^2 + (2.06)^2} = \sqrt{312.23 + 4.24} = \sqrt{316.47} = 17.79$ Œ©

Rotor (stator) current: $I_2' = \frac{V_{ph}}{Z} = \frac{230.94}{17.79} = 12.98$ A

(d) Calculate Rotor Copper Loss per Phase:

Rotor copper loss per phase: $P_{cu,rotor} = (I_2')^2 \times R_2'$

$P_{cu,rotor} = (12.98)^2 \times 0.5 = 168.48 \times 0.5 = 84.24$ W

Or using slip relationship:

Power across air gap per phase = $(I_2')^2 \times \frac{R_2'}{s} = 168.48 \times \frac{0.5}{0.03} = 2808$ W

Rotor copper loss = $s \times P_{ag} = 0.03 \times 2808 = 84.24$ W ‚úì

Final Answers:
(a) Synchronous speed = 1500 rpm
(b) Rotor speed = 1455 rpm
(c) Rotor current per phase = 12.98 A
(d) Rotor copper loss per phase = 84.24 W
(Total 3-phase rotor copper loss = 252.72 W)
